maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Lawyer, editor, army officer, diplomat, and presidential secretary. Correspondence, journals, draft messages of Andrew Jackson, diplomatic papers, newsclippings, scrapbook, sketches, photos, and other papers covering Donelson's career as aide-de-camp and secretary to Andrew Jackson, charge d'affaires to Texas, minister to Prussia, editor of the Washington Union, and candidate for vice president. Includes papers of Donelson's wife, Emily Tennessee Donelson, daughter, Mary Emily Donelson, and other family material. Also original documents relating to the ratification of the Constitution by Virginia.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Burke, Pauline Wilcox. Pauline Wilcox Burke papers.
Donelson, Emily Tennessee, 1807-1836. Emily Tennessee Donelson papers.
Martin, James Glasgow. James Glasgow Martin papers.
Randolph, Meriwether Lewis, 1810-1837. Meriwether Lewis Randolph papers.
Wilcox, Mary Emily Donelson, 1829-1905. Mary Emily Donelson Wilcox papers.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Andrew Jackson Donelson, lawyer, editor, army officer, diplomat, and presidential secretary were acquired in 1917 from Bettie M. Donelson, Nashville, Tenn. Small, but important, additions were between 1919 and 1972 by Robert Dyas, of Nashville, and others. In 1942 Pauline Wilcox Burke gave a group of Emily Tennessee Donelson's papers, and in 1948 an album of Mary Emily Donelson's was acquired from the same source. Burke's own notes, photocopies, and transcripts relating to the Donelsons, as well as some original manuscript letters, were bequeathed to the Library in 1954.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Donelson Papers were processed in 1970 and prepared for microfilming in 1971. One item, a photograph of Bettie M. Donelson tipped into the bound volume of the papers of Emily Tennessee Donelson in Container 21, was added to the collection in 1972 subsequent to filming. The finding aid was revised in 2010 and again in 2011.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Andrew Jackson Donelson is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Andrew Jackson Donelson are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.dd

altformavail.head: Microfilm
altformavail.p: A microfilm edition of part of these papers is available on fourteen reels. Consult reference staff in the Manuscript Division concerning availability for purchase or interlibrary loan. To promote preservation of the originals, researchers are required to consult the microfilm edition.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container or reel number, Andrew Jackson Donelson Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born, near Nashville, Tenn.
Became ward of Andrew Jackson
Appointed cadet, United States Military Academy, West Point, N.Y.
Graduated, United States Military Academy, West Point, N.Y.
Aide-de-camp to General Andrew Jackson at Nashville, Tenn., and in Florida
Resigned from the army
Studied law, Transylvania University, Lexington, Ky.
Admitted to bar, Nashville, Tenn., and commenced practice there

chronitemset.event: Married Emily Tennessee Donelson, a cousin
Assisted Andrew Jackson in unsuccessful presidential campaign of 1824

chronitem.event: Engaged in legal practice in Nashville, Tenn., and farming near Nashville
Assisted Andrew Jackson in successful campaign for presidency
private secretary and confidential advisor to President Andrew Jackson, residing at White House
Death of Emily Tennessee Donelson
Returned to Tennessee
Married Elizabeth Martin Randolph, widow of Lewis Randolph
Chargé d'affaires to Republic of Texas
Minister to Prussia
Minister to Federal Government of Germany
Edited Washington Union
Vice-presidential candidate on the Millard Fillmore ticket, American Party
Died, Memphis, Tenn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Andrew Jackson Donelson extend from 1779 to 1943, although they are principally for the period from 1813-1869. Letters received by Donelson constitute the bulk of the papers, but retained contemporary copies and drafts of letters sent are present, as well as transcripts and photocopies. Also included are a letter copybook of Donelson's dispatches from Berlin, 1846-1848, a few drafts of speeches, legal and financial papers, photographs, engravings, and printed matter. The collection is arranged in six series: General Correspondence and Other Papers , Additional Correspondence , Letter Copybook , Miscellaneous Papers , Family Papers , and Printed Matter, Documents and Indexes.

Others represented in the Andrew Donelson Papers by distinct but lesser groups of material are Emily Tennessee Donelson, wife of A.J. Donelson, a volume containing correspondence, journal entries, and photographs; Mary Emily Donelson, daughter of Andrew Donelson, an album, diary, and scrapbook, with some correspondence; James Glasgow Martin and Lewis Randolph, correspondence, journals, and notebooks; and Pauline Wilcox Burke, great-granddaughter of Andrew Donelson, correspondence, notes, and research materials.

The major portion of the collection relates to the Donelson's public life, as a cadet at West Point, military aide and private secretary to his uncle, Andrew Jackson, diplomat in Mexico and Germany, editor, and political candidate. Very few items relate to the Civil War period or to the years thereafter.

Andrew Donelson was closely associated with Andrew Jackson from early youth until the latter's death in 1845. Whenever the two were separated, Jackson would write frequent letters to his nephew, discussing matters large and small. Jackson is, then, a major figure in the Donelson papers, and there are some 250 of his letters in the collection. Many drafts and fair copies of Jackson's presidential messages and proclamations were once a part of the Donelson Papers, but were placed with the Library's Jackson Papers some years ago.

Among the many subjects touched upon by correspondence in the Donelson papers are Jackson's presidential campaigns of 1824, 1828, and 1832, the Eaton affair, the resulting Donelson-Jackson breach, and the subsequent cabinet reorganization of 1831. The move to recharter the Bank of the United States, nullification, the Poindexter incident, French spoliation claims, removal of deposits, and other issues of Jackson's presidency are also subjects of correspondence. There are many letters from office seekers and from others hoping to influence President Jackson through his secretary. Family affairs and plantation matters, especially the management of slaves and the breeding and training of horses, are frequent topics of correspondence.

Donelson's diplomatic career, as chargé d'affaires at the time of the annexation of Texas, and as minister to Prussia and Germany, is developed in correspondence and in the case of Germany, copies of dispatches. His brief political career, with the American Party, is not as fully portrayed as other aspects of his life, and very little is available to document the later years spent out of public service.

A small, but highly unusual, group of material in the collection consists of documents relating to Virginia's ratification of the United States Constitution, 1787-1788. Included is a Dunlap and Claypoole printing of the Constitution with holograph annotations by Edmund Pendleton.

The roster of prominent correspondents in the Donelson Papers is long and varied. Presidents in addition to Jackson represented by correspondence are James Monroe, Martin Van Buren, John Tyler, James K. Polk, Zachary Taylor, Millard Fillmore, Franklin Pierce, and James Buchanan. Many of Jackson's cabinet members are included, such as Edward Livingston, Louis McLane, Roger Brooke Taney, Levi Woodbury, John Henry Eaton, Lewis Cass, Benjamin F. Butler, Amos Kendall, John Branch, and William J. Duane.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in six series:
Bound volumes arranged chronologically. Volumes 17 and 18 are undated. Volumes 1-7 are item indexed.

p.emph: Index available in Manuscript Division Reading Room and on Reel 14 of the microfilm.

scopecontent.p: Speeches, legal papers, and accounts of Donelson. Transcriptions and photocopies of letters of Andrew Jackson, Andrew Jackson Donelson, and others. Also biographical sketches of Jackson, Andrew Jackson Donelson, and Mary Smith Donelson.
Papers of Emily Tennessee Donelson, Mary Emily Donelson, James Glasgow Martin and Lewis Randolph, and Pauline Wilcox Burke.

scopecontent.p: Printed matter and documents relating to the ratification of the Constitution by Virginia.

p.emph: The indexes are not part of the collection, but are available in the Manuscript Division Reading Room and at the end of Reel 14 of the microfilm edition.

did.unittitle: Documents relating to Virginia's ratification of the United States Constitution, 1787-1788 (oversize)

Memoranda (excerpts from Journal of the Convention , with other notes by William Brent, Jr.)
Journal of the Convention of Virginia , June 1788 (printed by Augustine Davis, 42 pages, with notes in an unidentified hand)
